item.name: Ofuda
entries: Ofuda is a piece of paper with mystical writings. You treat them as a simple ranged weapon, which has the the light, thrown(20/80), and finesse properties. They deal 1d4-1 bludgeoning damage on a hit, and whenever you would make an unarmed strike, you may replace any number of these attacks with an ofuda attack, and if you spent at least 1 ki point this turn they instead deal radiant damage. They cost 6 cp, and their weight is negligible.

item.name: Shuriken
entries: A Shuriken is a small piece of metal with sharpened edges, designed for throwing. A Shuriken can't be used as a melee weapon. Although they are thrown Weapons, Shuriken are treated as ammunition for the purposes of drawing them, crafting masterwork or otherwise special versions of them, and what happens to them after they are thrown. A variant lore of the classic {@item Dart|PHB}

race.name: Spirit Folk Tsìn
entries: Your spirit folk character has a number of traits shared between the five subraces.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Wisdom score increases by 2.

entries.name: Age
entries: Spirit folk age at the same rate as humans, but can live up to 120 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Perhaps because of their strong ties to the natural world, spirit folk tend to seek balance between extremes. They tend toward neutral alignments.

entries.name: Size
entries: Spirit folk are of comparable size and weight to humans. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Speak with Small Beasts
entries: Through sounds and gestures, you can communicate simple ideas with Small or smaller beasts.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write {@language Common|PHB} and one language of your choice.

entries.name: Subraces
entries: There are five spirit folk subraces: bamboo spirit folk, lung spirit folk, river spirit folk, mountain spirit folk, and sea spirit folk.

entries.name: Spirit Folk Tsìn
entries: Amidst the bamboo forests of the Island of Zhudao, a lone man silently walks. He leaves no trails, and his presence seems almost supernatural, as if he truly isn't there, but he is betrayed by his collection of fruits and roots from the flora.

The man's existence borders between that of a spirit and that of a human. He is but a part of nature that has manifested itself through generations, keeping its properties safe while taking only what he needs, and nature in return aids him to the best of his abilities, hiding him from predators and providing him with food to help feed him and his clan.

entries.name: Seishin's Elves
entries: While the spirit folk are in no way related biologically to the elves, they share some appearances with their pointed ears, and their connections to nature. In fact, spirit folk may host a stronger connection to nature than even the purest blooded eladrin, as the spirit folk derive their origins from the trees, mountains, and water that surrounds their way of life, choosing to forgo city styled civilization for that of villages, and town, and advanced houses for more open designed architecture that might only be seen by the likes of the firbolg.

Due to these reasons, one not native to the Seishin Isles would be mistaken in assuming what they are witnessing is another subraces of elf. And while elves do exist in the Seishin Isles, they are quite rare, to the point where only a small gathering of clans can be found.

entries.name: Spirit of Natures
entries: Spirit folk derive their powers and heritage from the spirits of the world. Everything in the world holds a spirit, from the tiniest rock to the tallest tree. Millenia ago, when humans first started settling the Seishin Isles, the spirits of the rivers, oceans, forests, and mountains walked the earth, and proceeded to fall in love with the new race, leaving offspring that are now known as the Spirit folk.

In modern times, the spirits that once roamed the lands freely have become dormant, with only the mighty Lung still roaming the mortal realm. Despite the loss of their ancestors in their life, the Spirit folk have ingrained their respect for the spirits in their culture and believe themselves the living proof that spirits exist.

entries.name: Spirit Folk Names
entries: Descendants of humans and spirits, the spirit folk will often take human names, though their given names often reflect their ancestry.

entries.name: Male Names
entries: Li Wei, Li Qiang, Wang lei, Wang Wei, Zhang Wei

entries.name: Female Names
entries: Li Na, Li Xiu Ying, Wang Fang, Wang Xiu Ying, Zhang Xiu Ying

entries.name: Ancestry Names
entries: Hǎi, Hé, Hú, Sēnlín, Shān, Shù, Shuǐ, Zhú

OUR FINAL DESTINATION, THE WEST ISLANDS OF THE ARCHIPELAGO, was somewhat shocking in comparison to the other islands and empires. While we had grown accustomed to their senses of fashion and their unique but intricate structures, almost none of that was to be found. The region belonged to a group of humans who call themselves spirit folk, and all their settlements are no bigger than towns, and very holistic in design, as to keep them close to the natural environments that they derive their ancestry from. The only notable exception is their central city where their empress resides, but even that is so ingrained in nature that it puts some elven cities to shame.

race.name: Kitsune Tsìn (Trickery)
entries: Your kitsune character has an assortment of inborn abilities, part and parcel of the kitsune nature.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Charisma score increases by 2 and your Dexterity score by 1.

entries.name: Age
entries: Kitsune mature and reach adulthood at about the same rate as humans and can live up to 1,000 years even though their average lifespan is usually 850 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Kitsune tend to be more chaotic and are only very rarely evil.

entries.name: Size
entries: Kitsune are generally on the smaller side of most humanoids ranging from 4'7 to the tallest being just under 5'9. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Masked form
entries: As an action, you can take the form of a specific human being of the same sex. This form is the same each time the ability is used, and you cannot use any type of attack involving bites while using this ability. If someone wishes to see your true form, they must pass an Investigation or Perception test with CD 10 + your Deception modifier.

entries.name: Fox Fire
entries: Because of your connection to magic and your fairy heritage you are able to cast the {@spell dancing lights|PHB} trick. Your spellcasting skill for this spell is Charisma and the dancing lights will always appear as blue flames.

entries.name: Kitsune tails
entries: All kitsune have at least one tail. In addition they gain an additional tail at levels 3 5, 8 12 15 and 17. Each new tail adds 1 Charisma OR 1 Dexterity to your score, however the kitsune cannot gain Charisma and Dexterity through the characteristic increases given by level increases. There is still a great mystery surrounding the legends concerning the eighth and ninth tails.

entries.name: Agile
entries: Gain proficiency in the skill in Acrobatics.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write {@language Common|PHB} and {@language Sylvan|PHB}.

entries.name: Kitsune Tsìn (Trickery)
entries: Hailing from the lands of Seishin, East of the Continent of Occidentra, the Kitsune are an ancient race of illusionists, having developed a culture around their leaders' worship, and being recognized as one of the most powerful dynasties in the Seishin isles.

entries.name: Fox-Like Cunning
entries: The Kitsune are a smart race, placing significance on the belief that the strongest warriors can outsmart an opponent before they have to overpower one. Utilizing sly words, and enacting on apparent emotions, the Kitsune can beguile others around them with words alone, and magic to enhance it.

Through Clever manipulation, of other races and themselves, the Kitsune rose to power over centuries and millenia, forming a powerful empire upon the southern isle. While other races live among them, such as the Tanuki and Nekomata, the Kitsune have been able to maintain their rule, while keeping the other kingdoms from initiating wars against them by pitting their kingdoms attentions elsewhere.

entries.name: Mask Warrior
entries: An interesting aspect of their culture, and one that is repeatedly seen withing the Seishin isles, is their affinity for mask craft, and their use of masks in combats and uniform. Even the Empress carries a mask, though she only ever appears to wear it when outside her domain, or when in combat practice.

In truth, like all masks within the Seishin Isles, there is both a cultural and practical significance to it. The masks of the Kitsune, especially amidst the nobility and high-ranking military, can act as a spellcasting focus for the Kitsune, and some can even prevent divination magic from being casted upon the wearers. They also help to hide the Kitsunes emotions in combat as well as creep their enemies out.

entries.name: Fae Descent
entries: A most shocking revelation to most, the Kistsune can trace their origins back to the Mystramm, having traveled to the Seishin Iles sometime during the 2nd or 3rd Eras and claim to have direct blood relations to the ancient Archfey of the Wilderbeasts, Piztiak. It is from these blood ties that the Kitsune were able to develop vast control over magics of the illusionary domain.

entries.name: Kitsune Names
entries: Kitsune use names from their local culture, sounding quite different to those who do not hail from Seishin.

entries.name: Male Names
entries: Akira, Kaien, Ren, Roku, Tsuki

entries.name: Female Names
entries: Kauri, Kazane, Rumia, Shion, Yuna

THEY WERE QUITE EXQUISIE, THE KITSUNE. WEARING FINE GARBS, with their tails full out for display, we were amazed. Finally, we were brought to the waiting chamber of their leader. Standing up to greet us, her appearance was hypnotic. Her hair was as white as snow, and her 9 tails on full display for us to witness. She would have succeeded with her spell, had I not caught onto what she was doing.

race.name: Nezumi Tsìn
entries: Your nezumi character has an assortment of inborn abilities, part and parcel of the nezumi nature.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Dexterity score increases by 2 and your Intelligence score by 1.

entries.name: Age
entries: They have a shorter lifespan than humans. They reach maturity at about 6 months and do not live more than 60 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: They have a markedly chaotic lifestyle; the contrast between their criminal activities and their community way of life pushes them toward neutrality.

entries.name: Size
entries: They are between 2.9 ft. and 3.9 ft. tall and weigh no more than 88 lb.. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 25 feet.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Pack Tactics
entries: You have advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Rat Claws
entries: Thanks to your claws you have a climbing speed of 18 ft., plus they are natural weapons that you can use to make a weaponless strike whose damage will be sharp instead of blunt.

entries.name: Bleak Circumstances
entries: You are immune to disease and have resistance to {@damage poison} damage.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can read and write {@language Common|PHB}, {@language Goblin|PHB} and {@language Nezumi|COMLanguage}.
The Nezumi dialect is almost its own language, full of snapping and squeaking, yet it is written in Dwarven and there are enough words in common to make communication possible.

entries.name: Nezumi Tsìn
entries: Nezumi are a race of rat like people who usually live on the fringes of society. Nezumi almost invariably arouse suspicion and mistrust any where they go. They are generally seen as thieves and criminals, and not without reason. Their ancient home of Takenuma was a treacherous place filled with great dangers, as a result the nezumi have evolved a culture where survival is the only goal. This conflicts with the codes of honor held in such high esteem by many humans and kitsune, for nezumi these are luxuries they cannot afford. Organised into gangs, nesumi have since spread throughout the world, usually living among the poor and destitute of the world.

entries.name: Physical Characteristics
entries: Nezumi have slightly hunched frames with rat like heads and a long tail. A noticeable difference between nezumi and humans are their legs, which in the case of nezumi are digitigrade, resting on their toes rather than the flats of their feet. Nezumi often to have slouched forms, though this is usually a result of habit, caused by constant crouching, hiding and skulking. Nezumi are covered in coarse fur, usually in shades of grey, brown or black. Females nezumi can grow longer hair on their heads much like human hair, this hair is of the same colour as their fur. The eyes of the nezumi are usually yellows, browns, blacks and dull reds. Nezumi are also more likely than other races to develop albinism, which results in white furred individuals with bright, blood red eyes.

Nezumi are taller than humans, however their tendency to slouch makes them appear roughly equal to the height of humans. Their builds are similar to humans under normal circumstances, but their skeletal structure is such that they can contort their bodies, allowing them to squeeze into smaller spaces easily. Like rats, their front teeth continue to grow and they often gnaw on various hard materials to wear down their teeth.

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: Despite the average lifespan of a nezumi being in the early 30s, they are actually capable of living close to 200 years. Most however die violent deaths well before then. The violence and danger of nezumi life is one of the only things keeping their population in control, as nezumi are born in litters or 5 to 8, most of whom die before they reach the age of twenty, often at their sibling's hands. Nezumi mature very quickly, usually by the end of their first decade. Those nezumi who do manage to live to old age will have long droopy whiskers, which continue to grow throughout the life of a nezumi. Old nezumi tend to retain their physical strength and dexterity, though they often are mentally unstable.

entries.name: Culture
entries: Nezumi do not possess what others would consider culture, instead what they do share is a strong instinct for survival, allowing them to adapt easily to whatever environment they find themselves in. This means that the nezumi have successfully adapted to all sorts of environments around Kamigawa and are often found outside their original home of Takenuma.

Nesumi social structure is normally in the form of gangs, those these structures are loose at best. Nezumi are instinctively social, seeking out groups for protection and safety. The exact social conduct of nezumi varies depending on the gang of which they are a part of. Some gangs are ruthless, cutthroat places where members regularly steal and cheat from each other and promotions are usually earned by murdering your superiors. Some gangs are more organised, some even have codified rules of conduct, these gangs tend to be rarer and fewer in number, though they tend to last much longer than more unruly gangs. Most gangs are lead by a boss, a nezumi more ruthless and cunning than the rest, who commands the respect or fear of the rest of the nezumi. The boss' personality has a direct effect of what type of gang it is.

In areas where nezumi are common, the gangs are almost invariably at constant war with each other, with bosses fighting for power. The gangs frequently split, merge or disband, as bosses are murdered, new bosses rise and powers shift. As a result it is common for a nezumi to be a part of multiple clans serving multiple bosses. Nearby lords seldom worry about the nezumi gangs, preferring to let them fight among themselves.

Nezumi also frequently find themselves in gangs which are not comprised exclusively, or even largely, of nezumi, with criminals of other races valuing the nezumi for their stealth and willingness to do work others may find unpleasant. Nezumi in areas largely populated by other races often find themselves as part of these criminal gangs as most consider nezumi untrustworthy and dishonorable, and thus refuse to hire them, at least openly.

An exception to this gang structure are the dark shaman of the nezumi. These individuals are mostly isolated hermits living in dark swamps and other treacherous places, studying dark magical arts, with necromancy and insect magic being the most common. Even other nezumi avoid these shaman, with most of them being slightly unhinged and all of them carrying a foul stench with them.

entries.name: Nezumi Names
entries: Nezumi almost never recieve a name at birth, as most are expected not to survive for long. As a result a nezumi's name is usually some type of descriptor for their physical or behavioral characteristics, given to them as they develop to identify them, like nicknames. As a result nezumi names are fairly fluid and distinguish little between gender. Some nezumi opt to continue using previous nicknames while others decide their own name. Also Nezumi can often have names similar to humans if they live in human dominated regions.

subclassFeature.name: Ninja Tsìn

entries.name: A Brief History
entries: Ninjas operate in the shadows, often as spies, assassins or guardians of secret knowledge. They may serve nobles, secret guilds or mysterious organizations, and are known for their talent for carrying out secret missions and deadly tasks. Ninjas are lethal and cunning agents, able to infiltrate behind enemy lines, eliminate key targets and disappear before their opponents can react.
Starting at 3rd level, martial arts practice confers the following benefits on you.

subclassFeature.name: Ninjutsu
entries: Starting at 3rd level, practicing martial arts gives you the following benefits:

items: While you wear no armor and wield no shield, your AC is 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier.
You gain proficiency in the {@item poisoner's kit|PHB}.
You can roll a d6 instead of the normal damage of your weaponless strike and use Dexterity instead of Strength for rolls to hit and for damage of your weaponless strikes.

subclassFeature.name: Kuji-kiri
entries: At the 3rd level, you can harness the mystical energy of ki. Your access to this energy is delineated by a number of ki points. You have a number of ki points equal to half your thief level (rounded up) plus your Wisdom modifier, which you can use to power your Kuji-kiri techniques. These techniques are a combination of ingenuity, skill, and magic. If you have ki points from another source, the points from both sources are combined and can be used to power any of your ki abilities; you can use your ki to duplicate the effects of certain spells.

At 3rd level, learn Illusion Technique and two other {@filter Kuji-kiri techniques|optionalfeatures|source=VGTROA|feature type=OPTFEAT:VGTROA:NINJA} of your choice. Learn one additional technique at 9th, 13th and 17th levels. Each time you gain a level in this class you can replace an old technique with a new one. In addition, you get the {@spell minor illusion} and {@spell control flames} tricks if you do not already possess them.

When you spend a ki point, it is not available until you finish a short or long rest, at the end of which you regain all your spent ki points. You must spend at least 30 minutes of the rest meditating to regain your ki points.
{@b CD of the spell's saving throw} = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Spectral Agility
entries: At 9th level, you learn to move like a spectre. When you use the sly action to sprint, your movement speed is increased by 3 meters, your jumping distance is doubled, you can ignore difficult terrain, and you gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and through liquids during your turn without falling while moving, if you are not wearing armor.

subclassFeature.name: Lethal Strike
entries: At 13th level, you learn how to make your strikes lethal to kill the enemy quickly. Your sneak attack die becomes d8.

subclassFeature.name: Counterattack
entries: At 17th level, you can take advantage of a creature's turn against it when it attacks you. Whenever you use your Prodigious Dodge, you can make an attack with a melee weapon or weaponless strike with advantage against the creature that is attacking you as part of the same reaction.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Miko

entries.name: A Brief History
entries: Miko are also called Shrine Maidens, and often develop into priestesses of the Shinto religion. They are always female, though male priests exist as well. Miko take vows of purity and chastity for their time of service; priests and priestesses have been known to marry. Miko and the priests are responsible for Shinto shrines and running/assisting worship and rites. In Wuxia, they also fight and banish unearthly entities like ghosts and other undead, spirits, true fey, demons, devils, and other outsiders. They seemed to be a natural for a Monk Tradition with a divine theme.
Starting at 3rd level, a monk of the Miko has the following features.

subclassFeature.name: Initiate of the Kami
entries: Upon entering service to a Shrine at 3rd level, the monk is initiated into Shinto. You gain proficiency in {@skill Religion}, and learn the {@spell thaumaturgy|PHB} cantrip, Wisdom being your casting modifier for this spell, as with other spells gained via this subclass.

Additionally, you become proficient in the use of {@item Ofuda|VGTROA}, a piece of paper with mystical writings. You treat them as a simple ranged weapon, which has the the light, thrown(20/80), and finesse properties. They deal 1d4-1 bludgeoning damage on a hit, and whenever you would make an unarmed strike, you may replace any number of these attacks with an {@item ofuda|VGTROA} attack, and if you spent at least 1 ki point this turn they instead deal radiant damage. They cost 6 cp, and their weight is negligible.

subclassFeature.name: Novice of the Kami
entries: At 6th level, the Miko begins to learn to use her Ki to connect to the spirit realm, and form spells. You can cast {@spell protection from evil and good|PHB}, {@spell branding smite|PHB}, and {@spell remove curse|PHB} spells for 2, 3 and 4 ki points respectively. When casting it in this way, branding smite can be used with {@item Ofuda|VGTROA}.
Additionally, when you cast a spell gained via this class, you can spend an extra 2 ki points, to cast it as if it were cast at a higher level. You can do this multiple times per casting.

subclassFeature.name: Adept of the Kami
entries: At 11th level, the Miko gains spells to truly act in her role against spirits and other outsiders. You can now also cast {@spell dispel magic|PHB} and {@spell magic circle|PHB} for 4 ki points, and {@spell banishment|PHB} for 5.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Mistress
entries: At 17th level, a Miko has reached the pinnacle of her power. Not quite a priestess, but quite capable of defending herself, others, and her shrine against evil forces. You can now, again, also cast {@spell spirit guardians|PHB} for 4 ki points, and {@spell dispel evil and good|PHB}, {@spell greater restoration|PHB}, and hallow for 6 ki points.
Finally, any spell casted through this subclass has it's cost reduced by 1 ki point, and upcasting as per Novice of the Kami now costs 1 ki point per level upcast.

optionalfeature.name: Technique of Illusion
entries: Once per turn, you can spend 1 ki point to fool a creature you can see. You gain advantage on your next roll to hit against that creature.

optionalfeature.name: Phantom Dart
entries: Immediately after making your attack action, you can spend 1 ki point to draw and throw two darts or daggers with a bonus action.

optionalfeature.name: Quick Attack
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to use your action to attack any number of creatures within 5 feet of you, with a separate roll to hit for each creature.

optionalfeature.name: Agile Mantis
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to cast the spell {@spell blur|PHB} or {@spell zephyr strike|XGE}.

optionalfeature.name: Sleeping Dragon
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to cast the spell {@spell burning hands|PHB} or {@spell scorching ray|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Spectral Prison
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to cast the spell {@spell darkness|PHB} or {@spell silence|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Phantom Passage
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to cast the spell {@spell misty step|PHB} or {@spell invisibility|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Crouching Tiger
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to cast the spell {@spell color spray|PHB} or {@spell hold person|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Crowned Gru
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to cast the spell {@spell gust of wind|PHB} or {@spell feather fall|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Bombs and Smoke
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to cast the spell {@spell thunderwave|PHB} or {@spell pyrotechnics|XGE}.

optionalfeature.name: Phantom Vision
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to cast the spell {@spell see invisibility|PHB} or {@spell darkvision|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Silent Chameleon
entries: You can spend 2 ki points to cast the spell {@spell mirror image|PHB} or {@spell Silent image|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Phantom Body
entries: You can spend 4 ki points to cast the spell {@spell gaseous form|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Fierce Leopard
entries: You can spend 4 ki points to cast the spell {@spell haste|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Drunk Monkey
entries: You can spend 6 ki points to cast the spell {@spell confusion|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Rising Phoenix
entries: You can spend 6 ki points to cast the spell {@spell fire shield|PHB}.

optionalfeature.name: Spectrum
entries: You can spend 6 ki points to cast the spell {@spell shadow of moil|XGE}.

optionalfeature.name: Minor Dragon
entries: You can spend 6 ki points to cast the spell {@spell freedom of movement|PHB}.
